channel.title: Post your Build
channel.description:
Inspired by [url=http://www.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,435042.0.html]this post[/url] i thought i'd create this and post mine in it.
The build itself is around 7 months old, I've upgraded some things in it since then like added the SSD and upgraded the case.
[ul][li]Core i7 920 @ 3.4 Ghz[/li] [li]Two XFX ATI 5850s[/li] [li]Corsair 800D case[/li] [li]Corsair H50 CPU Cooler[/li] [li]Corsair HX850W PSU[/li] [li]Corsair Dominator DDR3 1600Mhz Tri Channel 6GB[/li] [li]Intel X-M25 80GB SSD (& Samsung F3 1TB, WD 500GB)[/li] [li]Gigabyte-EX58-UD5[/li][/ul]
[img]http://i44.tinypic.com/vem6us.jpg[/img] 4 hot-swappable drive bays, 3 more inside [img]http://i44.tinypic.com/2ly357b.jpg[/img] [img]http://i42.tinypic.com/2s0hhdt.jpg[/img] [img]http://i43.tinypic.com/2dqr0af.jpg[/img] [img]http://i44.tinypic.com/2cr4myr.jpg[/img]
Now, post yours!

item.title: Post your Build
item.dc:creator: @sin21 sin2^
item.description:
@sin21 wrote:

[quote=“Phillipé, post:116, topic:338726”][quote author=Speljohan link=topic=435115.msg3909477#msg3909477 date=1328567086]

The cooling seems surprisingly good for a cheap case, however nowadays you can get far better looking cases (less plastic) for around 35 euros. My favourite budget-case company doesn’t sell in the US yet though (i think). http://www.bitfenix.com/global/en/products/chassis/outlaw/

EDIT: Actually it is being sold in the US, just not at newegg. http://www.outletpc.com/iv8237.html

I love corsair case’s, good quality and looks amazing (in most cases)
[/quote]They are far from budget though. For expensive cases i’m a Lian Li fan (i have one myself)

Lian Li’s are p cool but I’ve never, ever, and will never, ever use a case other than a coolermaster[/quote]
i buy coolermaster’s, they are always in stock on my local computer hardware store and there good quality for there prices.

Read full topic

item.title: Post your Build
item.dc:creator: @classic mopmans little slave
item.description:
@classic wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:99, topic:338726”]I bought 2 more sticks of ram for a total of 16gb, but when I installed them last night it turned out 1 of my old sticks were bad.

Anyhow, I took that opportunity to take some pictures with my phone, please excuse the dust:



Most of the cables are ran behind the metal the motherboard is mounted to, and that big mess up top is the extra cables from my non-moduler PSU that I stuff up above the DVD burner (which needs replaced), I should really get some zip ties to hold them back.

But there you go, a (I think) good looking case I paid $20 for with a power supply, but ended up getting for free because of the dent up top. Also the power supply only lasted a few months, so I got a ~$100 one on sale for ~$40, years ago. The power supply is from probably 2008, while the case is from at least 2006 or before maybe.[/quote]
looks stone age mitb

Read full topic

item.title: Post your Build
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

What about this, a bash script I whipped up to try all sorts of kinds (zip, gzip, bzip2, lzma) and levels (0-9 of each) of compression on all folders in the current directory, it runs 8 threads compressing many megabytes of data at all times:

#!/bin/bash
max_processes=8
#max_processes=0
NUM=0
QUEUE=""

# if max_processes less than or equal to 1, then just wait and return
if [ $max_processes -le 1 ] ; then
	function queue {
		wait $1
	}
else
	function queue {
		QUEUE="$QUEUE $1"
		NUM=$(($NUM+1))
#		echo "QUEUE '$1': $QUEUE"
		wait_processes $max_processes
	}
fi

function wait_processes(){
	while [ $NUM -ge $1 ] # MAX PROCESSES
	do
		checkqueue
		sleep 1
	done
}

function dequeue {
	OLDDEQUEUE=$QUEUE
	QUEUE=""
	for PID in $OLDDEQUEUE
	do
		if [ ! "$PID" = "$1" ] ; then
			QUEUE="$QUEUE $PID"
		fi
	done
	NUM=$(($NUM-1))
#	echo "DEQUEUE '$1': $QUEUE"
}

function checkqueue {
	OLDCHQUEUE=$QUEUE
	for PID in $OLDCHQUEUE
	do
		if [ ! -d /proc/$PID ] ; then
			dequeue $PID
		fi
	done
	#echo "CHECKQUEUE: $QUEUE"
}

function compress_extension(){
	ext=$1
	shopt -s nullglob
	for file in $(ls *.$ext); do
		for i in {1..9}
		do
			echo "gzip -$i $file"
			gzip -c -$i $file > $file.$i.$ext.gz &
			queue $!

			echo "gzip --rsyncable -$i $file"
			gzip --rsyncable -c -$i $file > $file.$i.rsync.$ext.gz &
			queue $!

			echo "bzip2 -$i $file"
			bzip2 -c -$i $file > $file.$i.$ext.bz2 &
			queue $!

			echo "lzma -$i $file"
			lzma -c -$i $file > $file.$i.$ext.lzma &
			queue $!
		done
	done
}

rm -f *.zip *.tar
rm -f *.gz *.bz2 *.lzma
#zip -6 -j complete508.6.zip complete508/*
for file in *; do
	if [ -d $file ]; then
		for i in {0..9}
		do
			zip -q -$i -j $file.$i.zip $file/* &
			queue $!
		done
		zip -q -Z bzip2 -j $file.bzip2.zip $file/* &
		queue $!

		tar -cf $file.tar -C $file . &
		queue $!
	fi
done
echo "waiting for zip files to complete"
wait_processes 1
#exit 0
compress_extension "zip"
compress_extension "tar"
echo "waiting for remaining processes to finish"
wait_processes 1
du *.zip *.tar *.gz *.bz2 *.lzma | sort > sizes.txt
du *.zip *.gz | sort | egrep -v "bzip2.zip$" > sizes_usable.txt
exit;

This is in addition to all the other stuff I was running before. It’s been running for about 5 minutes now and it looks like this is as hot as it is going to get:

mopar@killer-linux:~$ sensors
atk0110-acpi-0
Adapter: ACPI interface
Vcore Voltage:      +1.37 V  (min =  +0.80 V, max =  +1.60 V)
+3.3V Voltage:      +3.29 V  (min =  +2.97 V, max =  +3.63 V)
+5V Voltage:        +4.91 V  (min =  +4.50 V, max =  +5.50 V)
+12V Voltage:      +11.95 V  (min = +10.20 V, max = +13.80 V)
CPU Fan Speed:     3426 RPM  (min =  600 RPM)
Chassis Fan Speed: 1819 RPM  (min =  600 RPM)
Power Fan Speed:   2556 RPM  (min =  600 RPM)
CPU Temperature:    +49.0°C  (high = +60.0°C, crit = +95.0°C)
MB Temperature:     +42.0°C  (high = +45.0°C, crit = +75.0°C)

k10temp-pci-00c3
Adapter: PCI adapter
temp1:        +56.4°C  (high = +70.0°C)
                       (crit = +90.0°C, hyst = +88.0°C)

So, not quite 50C.

edit:
I spoke too soon, it got to 52C for an instant, then back down to 51 where it’s been since, so I guess that’s how high it goes. Not to shabby for stock cooling is it?

[code]mopar@killer-linux:~$ sensors
atk0110-acpi-0
Adapter: ACPI interface
Vcore Voltage: +1.37 V (min = +0.80 V, max = +1.60 V)
+3.3V Voltage: +3.31 V (min = +2.97 V, max = +3.63 V)
+5V Voltage: +4.89 V (min = +4.50 V, max = +5.50 V)
+12V Voltage: +12.05 V (min = +10.20 V, max = +13.80 V)
CPU Fan Speed: 4017 RPM (min = 600 RPM)
Chassis Fan Speed: 1901 RPM (min = 600 RPM)
Power Fan Speed: 2586 RPM (min = 600 RPM)
CPU Temperature: +51.0°C (high = +60.0°C, crit = +95.0°C)
MB Temperature: +44.0°C (high = +45.0°C, crit = +75.0°C)

k10temp-pci-00c3
Adapter: PCI adapter
temp1: +55.0°C (high = +70.0°C)
(crit = +90.0°C, hyst = +88.0°C)
[/code]

Process is done after about 30 minutes, this is how much data it processed (read and output):

mopar@killer-linux:~$ du -sh onefifty/cachetest/ 35G onefifty/cachetest/
51C is as high as it got.

Read full topic

item.title: Post your Build
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Teh Spede:

lol’d at killer-linux

My first computer I built I named ‘killer’, second ‘killer2’, this is my third, it’s named ‘killer3’, I’ve had this linux install since the first, so it’s ‘killer-linux’. No one ever accused me of being creative.

[quote=“Speljohan, post:103, topic:338726”][quote author=Moparisthebest link=topic=435115.msg3902349#msg3902349 date=1327874912]
I don’t think my temperatures are high:

mopar@killer-linux:~$ sensors
atk0110-acpi-0
Adapter: ACPI interface
Vcore Voltage:      +1.39 V  (min =  +0.80 V, max =  +1.60 V)
+3.3V Voltage:      +3.31 V  (min =  +2.97 V, max =  +3.63 V)
+5V Voltage:        +4.93 V  (min =  +4.50 V, max =  +5.50 V)
+12V Voltage:      +12.00 V  (min = +10.20 V, max = +13.80 V)
CPU Fan Speed:     2626 RPM  (min =  600 RPM)
Chassis Fan Speed: 1849 RPM  (min =  600 RPM)
Power Fan Speed:   2586 RPM  (min =  600 RPM)
CPU Temperature:    +36.0°C  (high = +60.0°C, crit = +95.0°C)
MB Temperature:     +46.0°C  (high = +45.0°C, crit = +75.0°C)

k10temp-pci-00c3
Adapter: PCI adapter
temp1:        +34.0°C  (high = +70.0°C)
                       (crit = +90.0°C, hyst = +88.0°C)

And it’s pretty hot in my room even.
[/quote]In idle, obviously not. Try pushing it a bit. My CPU hits at worst 43 degrees under load, and mobo stays below 35c at all times.[/quote]
I wouldn’t call it idle, I’m running Yakuake, Amarok, Firefox, Dolphin, Kate, all of KDE, Intellij IDEA and am compiling and running MoparScape every few minutes. I do think I checked it after running games and it never got above 45, but I’ll let you know next time I play a game.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @bootnecklad bootnecklad
item.description:
@bootnecklad wrote:

[quote=“Moparisthebest, post:62, topic:338726”]Stock heat sinks used to not be adequate when I first started building computers, like my AMD Athlon XP 2000+, which would overheat without overclocking. But all of the current Intel chips and AMD chips come with very good fans that are perfectly fine, as long as you don’t overclock a lot.

I’ll try to post some pics of my computer here in the next few days, to show you guys how good a <$20 free case can look. :)[/quote]

STILL WAITING!!!

item.title: Post your Build
item.dc:creator: @_bool
item.description:
@_bool wrote:

that you can pick parts (and have seemingly no clue why you picked them in the first place) and put together a computer at whatever age you are doesn’t impress me. especially considering you can’t even figure out how to follow the SMF documentation to install it.
my five year old sister could put together a computer if i gave her the parts.

Read full topic
